SEIZE.deftext:
to grab, take, grasp, snatch

SEIZE means “to take suddenly and by force,” to grab or snatch.

“The child SEIZED the piece of candy and ran off with it.”

SEIZE is often used about grabbing a chance or opportunity.

“I will SEIZE every chance I get to practice skating.”

The noun from SEIZE is SEIZURE.

“He said that the police’s SEIZURE of his car was illegal.”

Find is the most commonly chosen wrong answer in the Pretest. Finding something is not the same as SEIZING it, however.

Other forms of the word: SEIZURE, n.

GAINFUL.deftext:
producing a gain, profitable

A GAIN is an increase or a profit.

“The stock market made a GAIN of five points yesterday.”

Something which is GAINFUL produces a GAIN. () GAINFUL is used about jobs, businesses, and similar activities which earn money for the person doing them.

“After years of doing only volunteer work, she decided to seek GAINFJJL employment.”

“He was good at what he did, but it wasn’t a very GAINFUL trade.”

Other forms of the word: GAIN, n., v.

INDUSTRIOUS.deftext:
hardworking, diligent, busy

One meaning of the word INDUSTRY is “steady attention to business,” hard work.

“His success was due to years of steady INDUSTRY.”

INDUSTRIOUS means “full of INDUSTRY,” hardworking, and is used about people.

“He was a very INDUSTRIOUS student; he always seemed to be doing his homework.”

“You will have to be more INDUSTRIOUS in doing your job if you want to get a raise.”

The most commonly chosen wrong answer is brilliant. This is perhaps due to a confusion between INDUSTRIOUS and illustrious. Illustrious means famous, distinguished.

“You should be INDUSTRIOUS if you ever hope to become illustrious.”

Other forms of the word: INDUSTRY, n.

MANIAC.deftext:
a madman, lunatic

MANIA is a violent form of insanity or madness. A MANIAC is a raving madman.

“That MANIAC is chopping down all the trees in the parks.”

Often MANIA is used in a weaker sense to mean “extreme enthusiasm,” a craze.

“There was a sudden MANIA for collecting matchbook covers.”

MANIAC is also sometimes used in this weaker sense.

“He was a MANIAC for playing pinball. You couldn’t drag him away from the machine.”

Other forms of the word: MANIA, n.

OMIT.deftext:
to leave out, leave undone

To OMIT something is to leave it out, to fail to include it or do it.

“She OMITTED my name from the list.”

“I OMITTED doing my homework last night.”

“Please OMIT the first two pages and start with the third.”

An OMISSION is an act of leaving out.

“We were all upset by the OMISSION of his name from the list.”

Other forms of the word: OMISSION, n.

MYSTIFY.deftext:
to puzzle, make mysterious, confuse, baffle

MYSTIFY is the verb form of MYSTERY. To MYSTIFY means to make mysterious; if you are MYSTIFIED, you are completely puzzled.

“Does the difference between a prefix and a suffix MYSTIFY you?”

“The magician MYSTIFIES us with his tricks.”

“The police were MYSTIFIED by the unusual case. They didn’t know how to go about solving it.”

Other forms of the word: MYSTERIOUS, adj., MYSTERY, n., MYSTIFICATION, n.

ORIGINAL.deftext:
first, earliest, new

The ORIGIN of something is its starting point, its beginning.

“What is the ORIGIN of the custom of giving gifts at Christmas?”

ORIGINAL means “having to do with a beginning.” Sometimes ORIGINAL gives the idea of first or earliest.

“She had the ORIGINAL idea, then everyone else copied her.”

Sometimes the word gives the idea of new or fresh.

“There were many ORIGINAL costumes at the party. No one had ever seen anything like them before.”

Other forms of the word: ORIGIN, n., ORIGINALITY, n., ORIGINATE, v.

PREY.deftext:
a victim

Animals which are or can be killed and eaten by other animals are called PREY.

“The worm is the usual PREY of the robin.”

People can also be PREY when they are the victim of a criminal, a disease, or the like.

“The pickpocket carefully chose his PREY in the crowd.”

To “fall PREY to” something is to become a victim of it.

“Everyone in the family fell PREY to the illness.”

PREY is also used as a verb.

“The wolf PREYS upon the herds of sheep.”

REBOUND.deftext:
to bounce back, spring back

To bound is to bounce or leap. To REBOUND is to bounce back, like a ball when it is thrown against something.

“The golf ball REBOUNDED from the tree and hit him on the head.”

REBOUND is also used about someone or something that “bounces back” from a disappointment or setback.

“The movie industry is starting to REBOUND after several years of losing money.”

“Stan REBOUNDED from his illness to become more active than ever.”

SCAMPER.deftext:
to run quickly, scurry, move hastily

SCAMPER means “to run quickly or playfully,” to scurry about.

“The children SCAMPERED about the lawn as they played tag.”

“The mice SCAMPERED toward the hole when I turned on the light.”

The most commonly chosen wrong answer is jump up. SCAMPER is used just about running, not jumping.

SNARL.deftext:
to growl, bare the teeth, speak harshly

SNARL means to growl or bare one’s teeth like a dog. SNARLING indicates anger or hostility.

“The dog SNARLED at the cat to keep her away from the food.”

“The watchdog SNARLED in warning, so we went no further.”

When people SNARL, they don’t usually bare their teeth, but they do speak with a growling sound, to express their anger or irritation.

“The man SNARLED at the children in his usual unpleasant manner.”

SNARL is also a noun.

“The bad-tempered lady replied to his suggestion with a SNARL.”

OBSTACLE.deftext:
a barrier, hindrance, obstruction

An OBSTACLE is something that stands in the way of something else, something which stops progress or makes it difficult.

“They kept putting OBSTACLES in my way as I tried to walk up to the front of the room.”

An OBSTACLE does not have to be a physical object.

“Our game with Jefferson High is the only OBSTACLE left between us and the championship.”

“There are many OBSTACLES facing a person who tries to solve the problem of hunger in the world.”

SWAY.deftext:
to swing, move to and fro; to influence

SWAY means “to swing back and forth” the way trees do when the wind blows them.

“The flowers were SWAYING in the gentle breeze.”

“She was probably dizzy, because she SWAYED when she stood up.”

SWAY also has the meaning of control or influence. If you can SWAY something, then you can control its movement.

“The reporter tried to SWAY public opinion by writing misleading articles about the candidate.”

“Sam was SWAYED by their appeals, and finally agreed to help them.”

WITHER.deftext:
to dry up, waste away

When something WITHERS it dries up, it becomes stale and lifeless.

“Without water, the plants WITHERED.”

“His hope of success WITHERED as he grew older.”

To WITHER something is to make it dry up or become lifeless.

“Old age WITHERED her once great beauty.”

WITHERING is an adjective which means “able to devastate, destroy, or stun.”

“The WITHERING fire from the machine guns halted the soldiers’ advance.”

A “WITHERING glance” is a look which is intended to stun a person or make him unable to act.

“Susan’s WITHERING glance stopped Bob in his tracks.”

Other forms of the word: WITHERING, adj.

IGNITE.deftext:
to set on fire, cause to burn; to catch fire, begin to burn

To IGNITE something is to set fire to it.

“The burning cigarette IGNITED the straw.”

“He IGNITED the blaze with just one match.”

When something IGNITES, it begins to burn.

“When we threw on a few matches, the fire IGNITED.”

IGNITE is also used in a broader sense to mean to excite, inflame.

“Carol’s speech IGNITED the crowd’s enthusiasm.”

questions.prompt: Is it polite to SEIZE something from someone else?
Is a paying job a form of GAINFUL employment?
Do teachers usually like INDUSTRIOUS pupils?
Is a MANIAC a normal person?
Do people usually OMIT pages when reading a book?
Should a teacher MYSTIFY his students?
If something is ORIGINAL, has it ever been done before?
Does a stone REBOUND when it is dropped into the water?
Would some adults be able to SCAMPER?
Is a dog's SNARL a sign of anger?
Is it sometimes possible to get past an OBSTACLE?
Can a match IGNITE a forest fire?
He SEIZED us to agree with him on the subject.
Al didn't do any GAINFUL work until he was in his early thirties.
His first job when he arrived in this country was in an INDUSTRIOUS steel mill.
He drove like a MANIAC; we were all frightened to be in the car with him.
We were shocked by the OMISSION of these great athletes from the all-star team.
I am MYSTIFIED by your unusual behavior.
This was. the most ORIGINAL idea for a party that I've heard in a long time.
After losing ten games in a row, the team fell PREY to doubts about its ability.
The ball REBOUNDED from the wall and came straight back to him.
The kitten SCAMPERED around the room chasing the ball of yarn.
When Helen opened the present, she SNARLED with delight.
Lack of a college degree was a major OBSTACLE between Cynthia and success.
Jack's opinions were SWAYED by everything he read or heard.
The long illness had WITHERED him: he was only fifty years old but he looked eighty.
We managed to IGNITE the fire by pouring water on it.
